body.p: The objectives of this activity are:

ul.li: To teach you how to use to produce side-by-side boxplots and the relevant descriptive statistics,
To let you practice comparing and contrasting distributions, and
To help you gain more intuition about variability through the interpretation of your results in context.

body.p: The percentage of each entering Freshman class that graduated on time was recorded for each of six colleges at a major university over a period of several years. (Source: This data is distributed with the software package, Data Desk. (1993). Ithaca, NY: Data Description, Inc., and appears in http://lib.stat.cmu.edu/DASL/)

In order to compare the graduation rates among the different colleges, we will create side-by-side boxplots (graduation rate by college), and supplement the graph with numerical measures. Follow the instructions, and then answer the questions based on the output you got.

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: To open R with the dataset preloaded, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in R.

The data have been loaded into the data frame grad_data. Enter the command grad_data to see the data. There are 6 variables (column titles) in the data frame grad_data: College.A, College.B, College.C, College.D, College.E, and College.F.
You should see graduation data for six colleges over the past eight years. Copy the next command to see a summary of the data for each college:
By using the summary() command on the data frame instead of an individual variable, the summary statement of the five-number summary and mean are provided for each variable in the data frame.
Finally, copy the next command to see side-by-side boxplots of the graduation data for the six colleges:
Just as we did with the histogram, we can add x-axis and y-axis labels and titles using the same additional parameters in the boxplot() command, xlab=, ylab=, and main=. For example:
alternative.code: boxplot(grad_data, xlab="Colleges",ylab ="Graduation Rates", main="Comparison of Graduation Rates")
alternative.p: We can also modify the direction of the boxes by adding another parameter horizontal=TRUE. For example:
alternative.code: boxplot(grad_data, horizontal=TRUE, ylab="Colleges",xlab ="Graduation Rates", main="Comparison of Graduation Rates")
alternative.p: Notice that you must switch the x- and y-axis labels when you make a horizontal boxplot.

Note: Using R—Use the mouse to grab the corner of the graph window and change its shape. If you make the window wider, you see a label for each boxplot. While the graph window is the active window, try clicking the File menu. If you hold the mouse over "Copy to Clipboard," you see two ways that you can copy a graph for pasting into another document. This is how you use R to create data graphs for reports.

R coding Note for reference only: The above command works because all six variables are listed in separate columns. Data organization often plays a role in how you structure an R command. For example, if the data was instead organized into two columns GradRate and College in a new data frame called grad2, where GradRate contained all the numeric responses and College contained the labels A, B, C, etc., then the code would be as follows:

alternative.title: StatCrunch Instructions
alternative.p: To open the file (graduation.xls) in StatCrunch you must first right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Next click here to open StatCrunch in a separate window and login using your username and password.

ul.li: Click on the link “Open StatCrunch” at the top of the My StatCrunch page.
To open the data set, click on the Data button in the top row and select Load → From file → on my computer.
Under File, press the Browse button and select the data set you downloaded.
Scroll to the bottom of the page and click on “Load File.”
Choose Graph → Boxplot
In the Boxplot window select the column %_grad_on_time
Group by College
In Grouping options select "Plot groups for each column"
In Other options select “Use fences to identify outliers”
Press Compute!
Choose Stat → Summary Stats → Columns
In the Summary Stats window select the column: %_grad_on_time
Group by College
Press Compute!

alternative.title: Minitab Instructions
alternative.p: To open Minitab with the data in the worksheet, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in Minitab. Note: you will likely see a dialog box appear that says "A copy of the content of this file will be added to the current project"—just click OK.

ul.li: Choose Graph → Boxplot.
Under "One Y," choose "With groups" (top right) and click OK.
Under "Graph variables", type "%_grad_on_time" under Y (or double click on this variable in the panel on the left).
Under "Categorical variable for grouping" type "College" (or double click on this variable in the panel on the left).
Click OK.
Choose Stat → Basic Statistics → Display Descriptive Statistics.
Type "%_grad_on_time" in the "Variables" box.
Under "By variable," type "College."
Click OK.

alternative.title: Excel 2013 and 2016 Instructions
alternative.p: To open the dataset, click here to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in Excel. When Excel opens you may have to enable editing.

In the last Learn By Doing exercise, we calculated descriptive statistics for our entire dataset. This time, we want to calculate descriptive statistics for each college and then create side-by-side boxplots to compare the colleges graphically.
To start, we'll create a table that will list each statistical measure and the value for each college. When you are done, your table should look like this:

ul.li: To create this table, first make the row and column labels: in an empty section of your worksheet, pick a cell and type Statistic. Then move one cell to the right and type College A. Move one cell to the right and type College B. Keep doing this for colleges C, D, E, and F. Now, in the cell underneath Statistic, type min. Move down one cell and type Q1, then underneath that Median, then Q3, and finally Max.

alternative.p: Now for each statistic, we'll enter the formula to calculate that statistic and the range of data that corresponds to each college:

ul.li: In the cell to the right of min and underneath College A, type =min(B2:B9) because B2 through B9 represents the data for College A.
Now move one cell to the right (so that you're underneath College B, and type =min(B10:B17) because B10 through B17 represents the data for College B.
Repeat this calculation for colleges C, D, E, and F, adjusting the data range appropriately for each college.

IMPORTANT: Instead of typing the cell numbers inside of the parentheses, it is better to highlight the relevant cells with your mouse after typing =min( (by holding a left click as you highlight the cells).
In the cell to the right of Q1 and underneath College A, type =quartile(B2:B9,1), and repeat for colleges B, C, D, E, and F, adjusting the data range appropriately.
In the cell to the right of Median and underneath College A, type =median(B2:B9), and repeat for colleges B, C, D, E, and F, adjusting the data range appropriately.
In the cell to the right of Q3 and underneath College A, type =quartile(B2:B9,3), and repeat for colleges B, C, D, E, and F, adjusting the data range appropriately.
In the cell to the right of Max and underneath College A, type =Max(B2:B9), and repeat for colleges B, C, D, E, and F, adjusting the data range appropriately.

alternative.p: Unfortunately, Excel can't create boxplots directly, so we have to create a column graph and alter it so that we get boxplots. We start by using our Descriptive Statistics to create a new table that will be the basis for our column graph. When you are done, your table should look like this:

ul.li: To create this table, first make the row and column labels: in an empty section of your worksheet, pick a cell and type Statistic. Then move one cell to the right and type College A. Move one cell to the right and type College B. Keep doing this for colleges C, D, E, and F. Now, in the cell underneath Statistic, type 25th Percentile . Move down one cell and type 50th Percentile , then underneath that 75th Percentile, then Lower limit , and finally Upper limit .

The 25th Percentile values are the same as those for Q1, so select the values for Q1, right-click and select Copy, and then select the empty cells in the 25th Percentile row and right-click and select Paste Special . In the pop-up window, choose Values and click OK .

The 50th Percentile values are equal to Median - Q1 , so enter the necessary formulas to calculate those values from the values in your Descriptive Statistics table. For example, if the value for College A Median is in cell M4, and the value for College A Q1 is in cell M3, the correct formula for calculating the 50th Percentile for College A would be =M4-M3.

IMPORTANT: There is a shortcut for filling in the values for the rest of the table. First, ensure that you have entered the formula correctly as described for College A (check the example table). Also be sure that your new table is directly below your first table for descriptive statistics. Once you have the formula entered for College A, highlight that cell and move your mouse over the square in the bottom right corner. Drag your mouse to the right until you have reached the cell under College F. If you have done this correctly all the cells should now be filled with the correct values.
The 75th Percentile values are equal to Q3 - Median.
The Lower limit values are equal to Q1 - min.
The Upper limit values are equal to Max - Q3.

alternative.p: Now we can finally create our boxplots:

ul.li: Highlight the first few rows in your table—the column label row as well as the values in the 25th Percentile, 50th Percentile, and 75th Percentile rows, and then choose Column (the picture of bar graphs) in the Charts group on the Insert tab.
In the pull-down menu, choose the second option under 2-D Column (labeled Stacked Column if you hover your mouse over it).

Excel will create a stacked column graph for you. The idea here is that the top two boxes in each column will make up our boxplots. We'll add error bars for the min and Max values, and simply remove the bottom box.

Click on the top box in one of the columns to select it, and then press the Add Chart Elements button and choose Error Bars -> More Error Bars Options in the Chart Layouts group on the Design (Chart Tools) tab.
In the pop-up window, choose Vertical Error Bars on the left and then choose Plus on the right.
Choose Custom under Error Amount and then click the Specify Value button.
In the pop-up window, in the Positive Error Value box, enter the range of values in the Upper limit row in the table we created (or click and drag to select those values). Click OK and then Close.

Now repeat this error bar exercise for the bottom box in the columns, except choose Minus error bars, and enter the range of values in the Lower limit row of our table into the Negative Error Value box.

Right-click on the top box in one of the columns and choose Format Data Series. In the pop-up window that appears to the right, choose Fill on the left, and specify No fill. Then choose Border Color on the left and specify Solid Line.
Repeat for the middle box in the columns.
Repeat for the bottom box in the columns, except this time specify No fill and No line. This will cause the bottom box to simply disappear.
Click on the legend and hit the Delete key to remove it.
Click on the horizontal lines in the background of the graph and hit the Delete key to remove them.

Finally, right-click on the y-axis, and choose Format Axis from the pop-up menu that appears to the right. Make sure that Axis Options is selected on the left, and then next to Minimum enter 30 in the textbox. Click Close.

alternative.title: TI Instructions
alternative.p: To open a group of lists with the samples for the student survey data loaded, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and send it to your calculator. For instructions on how to connect your calculator to your computer and transfer a file, click here.

p.em: NOTE: This data set is fairly small (8 values for each school). It may be just as fast to enter the data yourself directly in L1-L6.

alternative.p: On the TI calculator, the dataset is displayed in lists L1-L6:

ul.li: L1: College A—percentage of students who graduate on time
L2: College B—percentage of students who graduate on time
L3: College C—percentage of students who graduate on time
L4: College D—percentage of students who graduate on time
L5: College E—percentage of students who graduate on time
L6: College F—percentage of students who graduate on time

alternative.p: Now use the TI calculator to calculate the numerical measures of a distribution:

ul.li:
Choose STAT/CALC/1:1-Var Stats. Specify which list the data is in:
If you don’t specify any particular list, the default list is L1.
To access one of the built-in lists (L1-L6), press 2ND and then the number of the list. For example, to access L1, you would press 2ND/1.
To access a non-built-in list, use the LIST menu (2ND/STAT). Press LIST/NAMES to choose the appropriate list.
Leave FreqList blank.
Highlight Calculate and Press ENTER.

The calculator will display:
x ¯
sample mean. This value is also the population mean if the data in the list are population data.
Σx sum of the x-values
Σx2 sum of the squared x-values
Sx sample standard deviation
σx population standard deviation
↓n sample size. The down arrow indicates that you can use the down arrow to view remaining statistics
minX minimum data value
Q1 first quartile
Med median
Q3 third quartile
maxX maximum data value
Either clear any equations you may have in your calculator by choosing Y=/CLEAR, or else toggle them off by choosing Y= and then pressing the left arrow until = is selected and pressing ENTER.
Choose STAT PLOT (2ND/Y=).
Choose 4:PlotsOff. Hit ENTER.
You should see:
Again, choose STAT PLOT (2ND/Y=).
Choose one of the available plots. For example, choose 1:Plot1…Off
Turn the plot ON by using arrows to highlight the word ON, then press ENTER.
Choose the Type: The fourth graph is a modified boxplot.

Choose the correct Xlist:
To access one of the built-in lists (L1-L6), press 2ND and then the number of the list. For example, to access L1, you would press 2ND/1.
To access a non-built-in list, use the LIST menu (2ND/STAT). Press LIST/NAMES to choose the appropriate list.
Choose Freq: 1 (the number one)
Choose the Mark you prefer.
You should see:
To view the boxplot, choose ZOOM/9: ZoomStat.

If you want to change the viewing window, choose WINDOW, and set the following values:
Xmin—this is the lower value for the x-axis. It should be lower than the smallest value in our dataset.
Xmax—this is the upper value for the x-axis. It should be higher than the largest value in our dataset.
Xscl—this is the distance between the tick marks on the x-scale.
Ymin—this is the lower value for the y-axis.
Ymax—this is the upper value for the y-axis.
Yscl—this is the distance between the tick marks on the y-scale.
Xres=1—this is the resolution of the graph. Leave it set to 1, which is most accurate.
Choose TRACE and then use the left and right arrows to move the cursor around the boxplot to see the values for min, Q1, Med, Q3, andmax.
You can display up to 3 boxplots on one screen by turning on three Stat Plots. Once you have all the boxplots turned on, you can choose ZOOM/9:ZoomStat to see all boxplots on the same screen.
Once you have side-by-side boxplots displayed, you can choose TRACE, then use the up/down arrows to choose one of the boxplots and the left/right arrows to display min, Q1, Med, Q3, andmax.
If you have more than 3 boxplots, plot 3 at a time and draw a quick sketch of each, paying particular attention to the scale and the 5-number summary.
